stories.text:
I'm currently an SRE, and I can't help but feel like engineers in my position are in a bit of a precarious position. Sure, there will always be a need for SRE/DevOps folks at large corps, but more and more PaaS seems to eliminating the complexity that my role is tasked with tackling.

Add to this that I really just like writing code. I feel like I write less code than ever before, and it's more an exercise in admin'ing services that come either prebuilt in the SaaS case or are generally stable in the run-it-yourself case.

Any advice on how to pivot? I'm still young and I've moved vertically pretty quick in my career. I just want to design systems and get in the "nitty-gritty" again.
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Move from SRE to SWE?
Poll: How many of you believe in Bitcoin (corresponding poll)
Pulumi Infrastructure as Code Goes Universal

stories.text:
This is an old lib I just rejuvenated, adding support for Unicode RegExps, properly handling back-references, and taking advantage of these to create helpers that make accessible things that are usually too impractical to use.

It lets you write anything you'd write with normal RegExps, but with a more readable syntax, and it lets you compose sub-expressions into larger patterns.

It also provides helpers like:

- `atomic()` that prevents the engine from backtracking into what you passed as argument. No more ReDOS.

- `bound()` works like `\b` but for arbitrary character sets. E.g. `bound(/[_\p{L}\p{Number}]/u)` is a Unicode-aware `\b`

- Set operations on character classes: `charSet.intersection(/\p{Lowercase}/u, /\p{Script=Greek}/u)` will only match lower case greek letters

I hope you'll find it useful!
stories.title: Show HN: Compose-regexp.js Build readable and maintainable RegExps. ReDOS begone
